topic.title: Tor Browser Update REEEEEEEE
topic.body:
Did the recent Tor Browser Update get rid of the "No Proxy For" option where you had to set 127.0.0.1 to be able to access zeronet?
I had to fuck around with setting network.proxy.no_proxies_on in about:config now.

1565908709_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
> [memesadler](#comment_89_194xi8BJsLXhwje1kBJETKo6tjvhHmK73S): I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX. [...]

No, Richard, it's 'Linux', not 'GNU/Linux'. The most important contributions that the FSF made to Linux were the creation of the GPL and the GCC compiler. Those are fine and inspired products. GCC is a monumental achievement and has earned you, RMS, and the Free Software Foundation countless kudos and much appreciation.

Following are some reasons for you to mull over, including some already answered in your FAQ.

One guy, Linus Torvalds, used GCC to make his operating system (yes, Linux is an OS -- more on this later). He named it 'Linux' with a little help from his friends. Why doesn't he call it GNU/Linux? Because he wrote it, with more help from his friends, not you. You named your stuff, I named my stuff -- including the software I wrote using GCC -- and Linus named his stuff. The proper name is Linux because Linus Torvalds says so. Linus has spoken. Accept his authority. To do otherwise is to become a nag. You don't want to be known as a nag, do you?

(An operating system) != (a distribution). Linux is an operating system. By my definition, an operating system is that software which provides and limits access to hardware resources on a computer. That definition applies whereever you see Linux in use. However, Linux is usually distributed with a collection of utilities and applications to make it easily configurable as a desktop system, a server, a development box, or a graphics workstation, or whatever the user needs. In such a configuration, we have a Linux (based) distribution. Therein lies your strongest argument for the unwieldy title 'GNU/Linux' (when said bundled software is largely from the FSF). Go bug the distribution makers on that one. Take your beef to Red Hat, Mandrake, and Slackware. At least there you have an argument. Linux alone is an operating system that can be used in various applications without any GNU software whatsoever. Embedded applications come to mind as an obvious example.

Next, even if we limit the GNU/Linux title to the GNU-based Linux distributions, we run into another obvious problem. XFree86 may well be more important to a particular Linux installation than the sum of all the GNU contributions. More properly, shouldn't the distribution be called XFree86/Linux? Or, at a minimum, XFree86/GNU/Linux? Of course, it would be rather arbitrary to draw the line there when many other fine contributions go unlisted. Yes, I know you've heard this one before. Get used to it. You'll keep hearing it until you can cleanly counter it.

You seem to like the lines-of-code metric. There are many lines of GNU code in a typical Linux distribution. You seem to suggest that (more LOC) == (more important). However, I submit to you that raw LOC numbers do not directly correlate with importance. I would suggest that clock cycles spent on code is a better metric. For example, if my system spends 90% of its time executing XFree86 code, XFree86 is probably the single most important collection of code on my system. Even if I loaded ten times as many lines of useless bloatware on my system and I never excuted that bloatware, it certainly isn't more important code than XFree86. Obviously, this metric isn't perfect either, but LOC really, really sucks. Please refrain from using it ever again in supporting any argument.

Last, I'd like to point out that we Linux and GNU users shouldn't be fighting among ourselves over naming other people's software. But what the heck, I'm in a bad mood now. I think I'm feeling sufficiently obnoxious to make the point that GCC is so very famous and, yes, so very useful only because Linux was developed. In a show of proper respect and gratitude, shouldn't you and everyone refer to GCC as 'the Linux compiler'? Or at least, 'Linux GCC'? Seriously, where would your masterpiece be without Linux? Languishing with the HURD?

If there is a moral buried in this rant, maybe it is this:

Be grateful for your abilities and your incredible success and your considerable fame. Continue to use that success and fame for good, not evil. Also, be especially grateful for Linux' huge contribution to that success. You, RMS, the Free Software Foundation, and GNU software have reached their current high profiles largely on the back of Linux. You have changed the world. Now, go forth and don't be a nag.

Thanks for listening.
FUCK NIGGERS

1565969602_112M71AbhUCyq3M7k8PLDRdELuQKG.body:
> [mido](#comment_15_1G2nXDHaHSiL2SV5w9jy1tWddBS5EegZMw): A human is not a goods.
A human provides a service, be it hard manual labour, a hairdresser cutting your hair, or a prostitute sucking you dry.
So communists agree that the first two examples here should be free, simply because you want it, and in exchange, you provide some service for free to the commune... if you feel like it... because of your social obligation to provide things to other comrades if you are able to and they want it.

So by commie logic, i get free sex with hot chicks? Right?

> [russianspy](#comment_10_1A3LTcwaXGFQJb7KDN4rbgYzNFQdAWEXa9): Prostitution cannot exist under communism. Prostitution is an exchange for money. Under communism commodity barriers are broken down and the means of production become collectively owned by the community; Meaning that there is no hoarding of resources that leads to exchange as a necessary general rule of the economy. [...]

Then make up some other word for it, who cares, you know what i mean.
If the basic service from a hair dresser and plumber is free, then it's also the case for prostitution.

If you imply that there won't be any prostitution because no chick will do it for free, then i have to ask you the question why you think that there will be some people readily doing all other shitty jobs that are neccessary for society to function, but that people just do because of money?

>Isn't prostitution done because it isn't free? isn't it just having sex at that point?
You can have sex because for procreation, or with your partner out of love, or because both find each other hot and want a quick fuck.

But prostitution is a service that a girl provides for you, she doesn't know you, she doesn't find you hot, You just buy 30min with her to release some cum.

So do i get free whores to fuck in communism or not?

1570109199_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdt.body:
You could take some complexity out of the proposal by letting every zite-owner itself  be the root node in your WoT for that zite.
You have to trust the owner of a zite anyway, when you visit it, and he is already in control of the content of the zite.

> [stardust666](#comment_4_16Fu36vdXG8dynYf9XUqN9F1za5xa19gHK): The authority is just a zite with a mapping in a certain format. The developer of each zite chooses which authority to trust. https://zeronet.io/docs/site_development/cert_authority/

Reading this, it means that in the current design it's not possible for a CA to sign a User Certificate that expires or to declare an already issued certificate as invalid. It's just a user/key mapping that's valid in all eternity.
That limits the ability to of dealing with spam or malicious behaviour a lot.

1573908669_1GDtf6kkYiCtruw42QmAeaHG1HsrW.body:
If a sponge grenade is the most brutal thing that happens there, in a riot where apparently millions participate, then i don't see much of a problem.
If that would be Detroit, that wouldn't be just a sponge grenade, people would die, and it wouldn't even be on the local news, because it's just an ordinary daily occurrence.

And that's why those protests look so staged, because it's full of fake outrage that wouldn't be an issue if it would happen literally anywhere else on this world. If you want support for your freedom fightersâ„¢, stop doing that. It smells so much like the arab spring, where we had the exact same kind of "news", and it ended up with fucking ISIS.

I don't even know for what they are currently rioting. They don't have any demands anymore. That one law that they didn't like got dropped a long time ago already. What do they want? Independence? How would that look like? Without China using HongKong as a Hub, they will experience an economic crash. Whats their plan of dealing with it? Will they then become totally independent on the USA or whoever pays? So from one dependence you switch to another?
Or do they want to replace the Chinese Commie Government to something that's not as horrible? That would be a legit concern, but for that they have to shill for mainland China support, but they don't do that, they are very eager to limit it on HongKong and not even Taiwan cares.

So what exactly do they want?
How do they want it?

> [z3n5if](#comment_78_17ZzQakCby5cKd1FduZm4DX7SYFZMVWYsD): It's better to deal with probable economic trouble now than definite oppression later.This is the same argument used to say that the UK should remain in the EU even though it's undemocratic.

Its the same argument, just that it's valid for HongKong, while its not valid for the UK.

The UK is a country that can and has been independent until at least the Maastricht Treaty 1992, producing it's own goods, not totally relying on the EU, able to feed itself, and that doesn't share the same ethnicity and culture with the rest of the EU.
Hong Kong is 92% Chinese, all it's wealth is based on being a trading Hub for Chinese companies, it can't stand on it's own, being independent from China would immediately mean to switch to being dependent on someone else (most likely the USA, which is on the other side of the globe, a totally different culture and they don't have a good reputation of taking care of their sock puppet states).

The plan for the UK is to go back to being independent like how it was before the EU turned into a repressive aristocracy.
What is the plan for Hong Kong? Do the rioters actually want independence? 
Because i really do not see any clear stance, maybe i am just not well informed. So they are actually separatists now?
